Award.AwardTitle: Addressing Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Anti-Racism in 21st Century STEM Organizations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Academies provides analysis and sound scientific judgment to inform policy decisions and to guide scientific endeavors. This project addresses the need for greater diversity within the science enterprise with the goal of making the STEM workforce a more accurate reflection of the population. It will synthesize what is known about longstanding inequities and historical, cultural, and institutional norms that have worked to the disadvantage of people of color as well as what is known about how to address these inequities. The project will articulate an agenda for organizational culture change to address racism and promote diversity as well as a research agenda to further advance diversity science. It is anticipated that the final report will provide recommendations for the benefit of both science and society.

In this project, a committee of experts will examine the extent to which systematic racism is a barrier to STEM careers for historically marginalized racial and ethnic groups; analyze data that point to effective approaches for addressing diversity, equity, inclusion (DEI), and anti-racism; and identify gaps in the research needed to support continued progress in DEI in STEM. Previous research has produced a rich picture of the factors that have shaped STEM workplaces, including longstanding inequities and historical, cultural, and institutional norms that have worked to the disadvantage of people of color and other marginalized groups. A key focus of this study will be on mechanisms to produce organizational change. Diversity science, a growing field, offers lessons on how to address the systemic barriers to full participation in STEM for underrepresented minorities. Application of these lessons can expand the intellectual depth of science by integrating new perspectives into the nature and process of scientific inquiry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite longstanding efforts to increase representation in STEMM fields, individuals from historically underrepresented groups continue to face significant barriers that limit equitable access to educational and career opportunities. Consequently, he Board on Behavioral, Cognitive, and Sensory Sciences at the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM)  appointed a diverse committee of expert scholars to produce a report focused on addressing the persistent challenges of antiracism, diversity, equity, and inclusion (ADEI) within science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and medical (STEMM) organizations. The final consensus study report was titled  Advancing Antiracism, Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in STEMM Organizations: Beyond Broadening Participation. This project aimed to address disparities in STEMM through a comprehensive synthesis of research along with actionable recommendations.

The report examined how systemic factors—such as historical, structural, and institutional racism—affect organizational culture and perpetuate unequal opportunities. One of the key findings of the project is that organizational practices such as recruitment, hiring, promotion, and resource allocation contribute to the ongoing exclusion of minoritized groups. These issues are deeply embedded in the ways that STEMM organizations operate and interact with broader societal norms.

In addition to analyzing structural factors, the report emphasizes the importance of integrating lived experiences as a valuable source of knowledge. Interviews conducted with highly successful Black professionals in STEMM illuminate the persistent presence of racial bias in the workplace and highlight the social and institutional barriers they confront, even in environments that espouse diversity and inclusion. These insights not only enrich the research base but also offer concrete examples of how racism affects individuals and teams in real-world settings.

The recommendations outlined in the report are intended to guide STEMM organizations toward more equitable practices. Among the key actions are embedding antiracism into policies, empowering gatekeepers with the tools to recognize and reduce bias, and fostering truly inclusive team environments. The research highlights that simply increasing numerical diversity is insufficient; organizations must also create conditions that actively support and include individuals from minoritized groups in order to increase recruitment, authentic participation, and retention. Additionally, sustained commitment is essential—achieving meaningful progress requires ongoing leadership, resources, and attention to ADEI efforts. The report also provides a robust research agenda that can help inform and catalyze future change.

The broader impacts of this project have already been significant, with widespread dissemination of the report across multiple sectors including policymakers, educational institutions, and professional STEMM organizations including government agencies and industry. In fact, as of this writing, the report has been downloaded in the top 2% of all National Academies Press products, reflecting a high level of interest and engagement from interested parties across the STEMM community. The report has also been referenced in proposed legislation. This robust uptake underscores the growing demand for resources that address structural inequities and provide practical solutions for fostering more inclusive environments. The high level of engagement indicates that the findings and recommendations are already being used to inform conversations and drive action. The hope is that this work will serve as a catalyst for lasting change, influencing how STEMM organizations address the structural barriers that have historically limited opportunities for individuals from underrepresented groups.

In sum, this project has made a substantial contribution to understanding how systemic racism affects STEM organizations and provided a roadmap for advancing ADEI within the field. The intellectual merit of the project lies in its comprehensive synthesis of existing research on organizational culture and bias, while the broader impacts are evident in its wide-reaching dissemination and the early adoption of its recommendations. As the report continues to reach diverse audiences, it has the potential to reshape the STEMM landscape and create a more inclusive future.
